document.text: Yery little if any of the fruit in this Section is left after so many severe frosts. Little gar dening has been done, all wait ing for the ground to get warm er. Tobacco plants are looking fine. A quantity of fertilizer is being unloaded at Caskie. It seems that farmers are making an extra effort for both corn anc tobacco throughout the commu nity. W. W. Thornhill, rural carrier from this office, has been on the sick list for several days. His substitute,  N Thornhill, is on duty Sam is alright, but the public will be glad to see W. W- on duty Again.  Mrs. J. L. Childress is slowly improving after a tiresome spel of flu. Her friends will be glac to see her well again. Little Charley Perdieu has been suffering with his throat, but is better now.   Miss Fannie Dixon has been on the sick list for several days We are glad to note that J. R. Marks is improving, hehas been on the sick list for several days Mr. G. W. Burks and Miss Maggie Stephens motored to Appomattox Wednesday, the 18th secured license and went to the parsonage at Vera and Rev Burnett performed the ceremony that made them one. They will reside at the brides home near Bent Creek. Rev. Gray L. Liggan preached to an attentive congregation at Maple Grove the 4th Sunday from 1st Samuel, 26th chapter, I Have Played the Fool and Have Erred Exceedingly . - The Sunday School is progressing nicely.

document.text: Wreck Island Home Dem onstration Club was the first Home Demonstration Club organized in Appomattox County by Miss Ella Smith Mrs. B. G. Anderson, home demonstration agent in July 1936. The first meeting was held at the home of Mrs. Cary Carson, Sr. in July of 1936, with Approximately 12 members present. There are three charter members remaining in the club Mrs. Elsie Thornhill, Mrs. Elsie Thornhill and Mrs. Tilden Lee. Today Wreck Island Club has an active membership of 19. .It. .meets the third Wednesday of each month. Club officers are president, Mrs. V. A. Staten, Vice- president, Mrs. Elsie Thorn hill secretary-treasurer, Mrs. Tilden Lee and Federation Goal Leader, Mrs. Ruth Carson. The Wreck Island Club members have actively particapted in county dis  trict and state events such as tours, workshops. Dist rict III Virginia Federation Clubs, State Federation H. D. Clubs and Family Resources Conference in Blacksburg. Members have exhibited at the Five County Fair, Farmville, Va. and the Virginia State Fair, winning a total of 850 ribons and cash money for exhibits and educational booths. In July 1971 Mrs. Tilden Lee was awarded the State Federation Award for the best Feature Article at the Suburban

document.text: Wreck Island Extension Homemakers Club celebrated its 40th birthday on May 27 with a covered dish supper at Hebron Baptist Church with our 40 members and friends present. Wreck Island Club was the first HD Club organized in Appomattox County by .Miss Ella Smith Mrs. B. G. Anderson in May, 1936. The first meeting was held at the borne of Mrs. Cary Carson, Sr. in May of 1936. There are four charter members remain ing in the dub. Mrs. Elsie CaidweU, Mrs. Tilden Lee, Mrs. Elsie ThornhUl, and Mrs. Irby Wheeler. In 1972, Home Demonstration name was chan ged to Extension Homemakers Club. Today Wreck Island Chib has an active membership of 19 members. It meets on the third Wednesday of each month. Club officers are President, Mrs. V. A. Staten Vice President, Mrs. Elsie ThomhiU Secretary - Treasurer, Mrs. Tilden Lee, Federation Goal Leader, Mrs. Ruth Carson and program Topics Leader, Mrs. Elsie Thornhill. The Wreck Island Club members have actively partici- pated in county, district and state events, such as tours, workshops, District HI Virginia Federation Extension Home makers Clubs, State Federation Extension Homemakers Club, and the 1969 National Exten sion Homemakers Council Meeting at VPI, Blacksburg,

document.text: Wrack Island Extension Homemakers Club Matting Mrs. Marie Carson was hostess to the Wreck Island Ex tension Homemakers Club when it met in her home o n  Wednesday, September 20, at H30 p.m. There were 12 mem bers in attenance. One new member, Mrs. Zolene Harding was added to the roll. Mrs. Elsie Thornhill led devotions and prayer. She chose for the scripture reading Matt.7l-5. She gave a reading. The topic was Fog Dims The View . Hie secretary read the minutes and it was approved and the treasurer report was given. Mrs. Dixie Staten led the group in the Homemakers Creed. A business session wàs con ducted by our president, Mrs. Dixie Staten of announcements with dates of interest to mem bers. September 23-24 - Railroad Festival - The Appomattox County Homemakers are preparing a float for the Railroad Festival . The Float Committee decided that one person from each homemakers gçoup will be on the float to sing. Mrs. Frances Dyess will represent our club. September 28 Leader Training for October. Dr. Eldridge R. Collins, Exten sion Specialist with Ag Engineering will do the Leader Training Session for October. Sessions will be held at 130 p.m. and 730 p.m. on Safe Wood Burning in Stoves and Fireplaces. September 30, 1978 Achievement Day - to be held at the Appomattox County High School cafeteria for the Ap pomattox County Homemakers at 6 p.m. The theme for this program is Todays 4-Hers Tomorrows Homemakers. Three of our members, Mrs. Rose Burnett, Mrs. Mane Car- son and Mrs. Dixie Staten have signed up for needlepoint workshops that Dr. Helen Whidden of Lynchburg is con ducting September 7, 8, 14, 15, 19 and 21. It was announced that Mrs. Tilden Lee entered exhibits on canned goods, horticulture and flowers at the Five County Fair in Farmville, Sept. 11-16. She won 24 ribbons on her en tries. Thirteen blue ribbons were won which was the greatest number of blue ribbons won in the adult division to win the Grand Champion Award Trophy plus 10.00. Mrs. Lee entered seven exhibits at State Fair,- Rich mond, Va., and won seven rib bons, 4 of which were blue rib bons for her entries. Mrs. Ruth Carson, Federation Goal Chairman, gave a program topic, A Goal For Everyone. Breads of the World was the topic of the demonstration given by Mrs. Rose Burnett. A social hour followed when the hostess served delicious refreshments to the group. The October meeting will be held in the home of Mrs. Mary Taylor on Wed., Oct. 18, at 130 p.m. A demonstration on Safety to be given. The topic Safe Woodburning - Stoves and Fireplaces. Mrs. Tilden Lee, Secretary

document.text: With the Vice President Dr. Merwyn Williamson presiding in the absence of the President, Mr. Gilbert Lusk, the Appomat tox County Historical Society held its regular October meeting recently. The resignation of the President, due to a transfer of professional duties to Gettys burg National Park was accepted with regrets. Highlight of the October meeting focused on a seven hundred dollar donatimi for historical research from the Woodmen of the W orld, donation of 1914 news articles and other documents concern ing the late Congressman Henry D. Flood, and the Birth Pangs of Appomattox County depicted in a talk by Mr. Ron Wilson. Mrs. Harry Clark Rucker presented the Flood news articles to the Glory of God and to the members of the society. To her the beauty of any possession is dependent on  the degree to which it is shared i with others. Amy possession to predoifl to share is not worth  having. The thing then becomes j the master of the man. Mrs. Rucker, the former j Helen Nowlin, the great-grand-1 daughter of Lawyer John Woodson whose office is one of ! the restored buildings at J Appomattox National Park, is i the daughter of the late Annie ! Thornhill and Albert Sidney ! Nowlin. Her mother, from the I Hollywood area of the county, and her father, from the! Oakville area, are widely j related throughout the county. The firuest speaker for the evening, Ron Wilson, Historian at Appomattox Court House Rational Historic Park, spoke on th e Birth Pangs of Appomattox County,1845 - 1870. The speech, based on research, one by Dr.  John Moore, Research H istorian, University of Virginia, depicted the February 8,1845 birthing of Appomattox County from the parent counties of Buckingham, Campbell, Prince Edward and

document.text: Winston Thornhill, Negro, was charged Saturday with breaking and entering into Percy Thomp sons Phillips 66 station, R t. 460, Appomattox. Sheriff Walter Conner, State Trooper W. W. Wilberger, and Deputy Charlie Rush recognized Thornhill and made the arrest Saturday morning at a county restaurant. Thornhill was wear ing eyeglasses allegedly taken from Thompsons station. Conn er said Thornhill has previously served time on similar charges of breaking and entering. Following a preliminary hear ing, Thornhills case was sent the Grand Jury for an April hear ing.

document.text: Winners in The Virginia Farmer, Yesterday and Today are pictured above with Mrs. Frances Gilliam representing the Appomattox County Farm Bureau Womens Committee. Pictured are Ronald Thornhill, 1st place Tom Cobb, 2nd place and Michelle Ford, 3rd place. Over 40 4th and 5th grade 4-H members entered posters in the contest sponsored jointly by the Farm Bureau Womens Committee and Appomattox County 4-H clubs. document.text: We were so glad to see Mrs. Elsie Thornhill at church last Sunday after her winter stay with her daughter, Mrs. Floyd Weidman, of Connecticut. Mr. Crawford Davidson had to be taken to the doctor in Lynchburg twice last week. He went again Tuesday. His niece, Mrs. Mary Barrel!, spent last week with him and Mrs. Catherine Judy is there to stay this week. Mr. Osborne is about the same with the good care Mrs. Becky Shanks is giving him. Mr. John Langhon is able to help with eating alone, but his speech is not so good yet. So our prayers go to each sick one. Mr. Tommy Davidson is still with his sister, Mrs. Davis Smith, in Lynchburg. Mr. and Mrs. Card Mince had Rev. and Mrs. Moore of Newport News, her mother and twot sisters to pend the Week end with them. Last Friday Mr. I. B. Wheeler had a slight stroke while shaving but got over it quickly with no effects, but he went on to the doctor. at Appomattox. He was not able to go to church Sunday. It was the first time he has- missed going to church Tor three years. Thanks to the Lord. Mr. Leslie Taddy, Mr. Lyle Gilbert, Mr. and Mrs. Ben Wheeler, Mr. Wallace Bondurant, Mrs. Ruby Newman, of Norfolk, and her girl friend, Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. Booker, Mrs. Barbara Jordan, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Krantz and daughters and Mrs. Elsie Krantz, Mrs. Elsie and Nina Caldwell, Mr. and Mrs. H. B. Jones and Richard all visited the Wheelers over the week end. Mr. and Mrs. John Osborne Harrison and family, of Louisa, spent the week end with Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison. So nice to have our children to come.

document.text: We understand that Judge Chris- tain will appoint Mr. Beauregaid Thornhill to be a member of the Board of Supervisors from Stone wall district, to fill the vacancy caused by Mr. Stratton resigning. Should Mr. Thornhill accept the position, he will do doubt make an excellent father, and will take a lively interest in all that pertains to the countys progress and good government.

document.text: We take the following from the Lynchburg News, of Tuesday  Misses Lucy, Sissie, Emma and Fannie Thornhill, and Miss Emma Harris, who have been visiting friends in Appomattox, returned home yesterday afternoon. Miss Anna LeGrand and her. sisters, Misses Isa and Fannie LeGrand,returned from Appomattox yesterday afternoon where they spent their Easter holidays.

document.text: We had lots of refreshing showers and crops and garden track are all looking good. We extend our deepest sym- were Pthy to Mr. J. C.- Harris and children in the loss of their loved one, wife and mother. Mrs. L. M. Thornhill who has been sick, is better. We are glad to say Mr. J. H. Thornhill is out again. Mrs. Frank Summons and sis ter, Miss Maude Brown, of Wash ington were guests of their aunt, Mrs. Ida Marks, Sunday. Miss Oiivia Booker has return ed home from hospital much im proved. Miss Alice Eubank, of Rich mond, who has been guest of Mrs. John Booker for several days returned home Monday. Miss Olivia Booker is visiting friends in Richmond this week Mrs. Carrington Carter has re turned home from a weeks visit with her sister, Mrs. Delia Doss of Lynchburg. Mr. Tom Beale who has been very ill. is reported better. Mr. Paul Thornhill, and wife, of Charlotte County were guests of his parents last week-end.
